ygData.subject: Re: Elitism
ygData.msgSnippet: The SharpNEAT elitism percentage is applied to each species.  So in my experiments the top 20% of each species will be preserved.  Given my target species

The SharpNEAT elitism percentage is applied to each species.  So in my expe=
riments the top 20% of each species will be preserved.  Given my target spe=
cies size, this probably works out to be about 2 individuals per species mo=
st of the time.  So, in answer to your question Jeff, my elitism is probabl=
y a bit more than twice yours.  I say a bit more because SharpNEAT also doe=
sn't have a minimum species size to qualify for elitism.  I'd be curious ab=
out the effects of setting a hard limit of 1 genome per species and minimum=
 species size requirement though.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <ksta=
nley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> I just wanted to comment on the elitism discussi=
on that has been part of the broader discussion of multiagent HyperNEAT.
> =

> In my NEAT implementation, elitism is not a percentage.  Rather, the cha=
mpion of each species is copied into the next generation as long as the spe=
cies is at least some minimal size (otherwise the species would never chang=
e).  Jason's SmallestSpeciesSizeWithElitism variable is about that.
> 
> Ke=
eping the champion of each species makes sense because it means the species=
 will all remember their best solution yet, rather than only the champion o=
f the top species.  I'm not sure what exactly the elitism percentage means =
in some other systems like SharpNEAT.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >
> > > Hi Jeff,
> > > 
> > > Thanks fo=
r your interest in our paper.
> > 
> > Hi David. No problem. Thanks for the=
 answers.
> > 
> > > In response to comments 1-3, we've actually run severa=
l preliminary
> > > experiments with the intent of answering the questions =
you've asked.  We hope
> > > to have a publication with formal results base=
d on those experiments soon.  In
> > > general though, we do feel that this=
 approach is superior to the one discussed
> > > in the previous multiagent=
 HyperNEAT paper and would recommend anyone who
> > > wants to work with mu=
ltiagent HyperNEAT to use the z-based substrate.
> > 
> > Cool. I look forw=
ard to seeing the paper.
> > 
> > > 4.  Way back when I first converted Sha=
rpNEAT to HyperSharpNEAT I tried a
> > > number of values and found that th=
ere wasn't a large difference between them,
> > > although 20% seemed to be=
 slightly better.  For any new domains I'll try a few
> > > values to see i=
f they make any difference, but I haven't found any where the
> > > elitism=
 value made a significant difference.
> > > 
> > > I will say that I've nev=
er tried just saving the best organism.  One reason is
> > > that the Sharp=
NEAT speciation code isn't really designed to only save one
> > > genome.  =
The other is that I think saving at least the best genomes in your
> > > be=
st species would help prevent promising species from accidentally dying off=

> > > too early.  On the other hand, I know you have several successful Hy=
perNEAT
> > > experiments, so I guess I'll turn the question back on you: H=
ave you found
> > > saving just the best genome to generally be better than=
 saving more?  I'm
> > > certainly willing to give it a try if you've seen =
much better results.
> > 
> > I have never changed these parameters. But no=
w that we are discussing it I
> > am realizing I don't actually know how mu=
ch elitism I am using. I think I am
> > using the same parameters from Jaso=
n's experiments. I was focusing on this
> > parameter, which is why I said =
I keep only the best org:
> > 
> > ForceCopyGenerationChampion 1.0
> > 
> >=
 But I now also see these parameters in my experiment config files:
> > 
> =
> SmallestSpeciesSizeWithElitism 5.0
> > MutateSpeciesChampionProbability 0=
.0
> > 
> > How do I figure out my % elitism, so I know how my number compa=
res to your
> > 20%?  
> > 
> > > 5.  The answer to whether we renormalize =
the sheets or insert the new sheets
> > > between the old is technically bo=
th.  In general we renormalize, that is
> > > however many agents there are=
, they are evenly spaced between -1 and 1.  While
> > > it may seem like a =
good idea to leave the original sheets where they were and
> > > insert the=
 new ones among them, in most cases it is difficult to determine
> > > wher=
e the new sheets should go.
> > > 
> > > For example, if there were 5 agent=
s located at z=3D{-1, -0.5, 0, 0.5, 1} and the
> > > team needed to be scal=
ed to 7 agents, where should the two new agents go?
> > > There are two age=
nts, but four spaces (-0.75, -0.25, 0.25, 0.75) to put them
> > > and no re=
al reason to choose any of the spaces over the others.  By
> > > redistribu=
ting the agents evenly we eliminate such ad hoc decisions.  However,
> > > =
if the 5 agent team were to be scaled up to 9 agents, they would be placed =
at
> > > z=3D{-1, -0.75, -0.5, -0.25, 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75,1}.  Thus, even th=
ough we're
> > > renormalizing, the placement works out the same as if we h=
ad inserted the new
> > > agents among the old.
> > 
> > That makes sense, =
and seems like the right way to do it.
> > 
> > > 6.  The sign function sim=
ply returns the sign of the node's activation: -1 if
> > > the activation i=
s negative, 0 if it is 0, and 1 if it is positive.
> > >The reason 
> > > f=
or this function and the starting structure is to establish a team with
> >=
 > mirror symmetry i.e. the ANN of the agent at z=3D 1 is the horizontally =
flipped
> > > version of the agent at z=3D-1 and so on.  We found that team=
 mirror symmetry
> > > was beneficial in both domains that were tested in t=
his paper, so it was
> > > logical to allow it to start with symmetry (whic=
h can be broken or ignored
> > > with mutations).
> > 
> > Ok. I get it. Th=
anks for clarifying.
> > 
> > > I hope I've answered your questions,
> > 
>=
 > You did. Thanks again for all the answers, and congrats on the great wor=
k.
> > 
> > -Jeff
> > 
> > > David
> > > 
> > > 
> > > --- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> > >> 
> > >> Congrats on this paper.=
 It features a lot of nice results.
> > >> 
> > >> A few questions/comments=
:
> > >> 
> > >> 1) The issue of interpolation is extremely interesting. In=
 this paper you
> > >> explicitly discuss how it would be beneficial to add=
 new agents, and have
> > >> their roles be intermediate versions of other =
agents (e.g., adding a 12th
> > >> soccer player between the forwards and t=
he midfielders would create a player
> > >> that was a hybrid of the two ro=
les). It would also be cool to see if teams
> > >> can gracefully re-divide=
 the strategy-space when they lose agents. For
> > >> example, in soccer/fu=
tbol, after a few red cards are assigned, each player
> > >> does not play =
the usual role that they would play on a team of 11, but
> > >> instead re-=
divide the space up amongst the fewer players. For example, after
> > >> th=
e red cards their may be a left and right forward instead of a left, right
=
> > >> and center forward. It would be cool to see if you can see such a re=
sult
> > >> using your method.
> > >> 
> > >> 2) You mention the benefits o=
f interpolated roles, but do you have any
> > >> evidence that such interpo=
lation is occurring? One cool way to test this
> > >> would be to compare t=
wo different treatments: T1) take your original N
> > >> agents and multipl=
y them to achieve the desired scaled-up number of agents
> > >> (e.g., 9, 2=
5, 100, 1000). If you start with 10 agents, and scale to 1000,
> > >> you t=
hus get 100 identical copies of agent 1, 100 identical copies of agent
> > =
>> 2, etc. Compare the performance of this treatment to T2) interpolate 100=
0
> > >> agents into the z coordinate range, so you have 1000 slightly diff=
erent
> > >> agents. The difference in performance between these treatments=
 will help you
> > >> figure out whether you are seeing a boost due to inte=
rpolation. If the
> > >> performance increase due to scaling is not differe=
nt between T1 and T2, then
> > >> you know your performance boost was simpl=
y due to having more agents, not
> > >> due to interpolation (you note some=
thing similar when you say "adding more
> > >> agents that all do the same =
thing will eventually cause a pile-up"...my
> > >> suggestion is a way to t=
est this claim).
> > >> 
> > >> 3) Why do you feel this new technique is be=
tter than your old technique? Is
> > >> it possible to compare the two expe=
rimentally? Have you done so?
> > >> 
> > >> 4) I notice you mention that y=
ou use 20% elitism. I usually only save the
> > >> best organism. Have you =
found 20% to work a lot better, generally?
> > >> 
> > >> 5) When you add n=
ew agents, do you leave the previous sheets in the same
> > >> place, and i=
nterpolate new sheets between them, or do you renormalize all of
> > >> the=
 sheets such that it may be the case that no new agent is in the exact z
> =
> >> coordinate of one of the original agents? It might be interesting to t=
ry
> > >> both and see which tends to work better.
> > >> 
> > >> 6) What i=
s the 'sign' function you mention in Figure 2? In general, I am
> > >> havi=
ng trouble figuring out what this means: "The starting structure of the
> >=
 >> initial heterogeneous CPPN (Figure 2b) includes some additional structu=
re to
> > >> start evolution with knowledge of mirrored team symmetry; in p=
articular, the
> > >> sign function of z connected to multiplication operat=
ors on the x-axis means
> > >> that the CPPN knows which side of the team i=
s which and can opt to reflect
> > >> one side across the midline."
> > >> =

> > >> Congrats again on this nice work.
> > >> 
> > >> Best regards,
> > =
>> Jeff Clune

ty

d D'Ambrosio and myself introduced the idea that

yperNEAT CPPN can encode a set of neural networks (instead of just

one) that represent a pattern of policies for an entire team.  Since then a=

bstrate

ehman,

such an alternative

 to appear in AAMAS 2010,

plex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2010/dambrosio.aamas10.html

irect Link: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/dambrosio_aamas10.pdf

 > >>> We believe this z-based substrate layout is superior to the previous=
 one,

n up the field

  The paper also includes the first

e size of the team without further training,

perNEAT can interpolate new policies for ANNs inserted

axis of the substrate.
